title: How to start producing electronic music - Quora

response.answer_text: There are a myriad of answers here. About half of them are from someone peddling a website or blog or school (never attend a school or college like Berklee to learn this stuff…and that's coming from a university faculty member!). The other half are peddling their sample sets or don't know enough about music production to be giving you an answer (hint: it's NOT about having a DAW, PC, MIDI controller, and studio monitors with a great audio interface…that's the bedroom producer gear loadout for sure, but it's not what to focus on). Do you want a simple, no BS answer from someone who isn't trying to sell you anything or have any connection to those who might benefit from his recommendation? Here:  Dance Music Manual: Tools, Toys, and Techniques Dance Music Manual: Tools, Toys, and Techniques: Rick Snoman: 9781138319646: Amazon.com: Books The Dance Music Manual by Rick Snoman (if you're reading this before December 29 of 2018, buy THIS version: Dance Music Manual: Tools, Toys, and Techniques Dance Music Manual: Tools, Toys, and Techniques: Rick Snoman: 8601404429132: Amazon.com: Books). Everything you need to get started and become very proficient is right in there. Music theory? Check. Synthesizers? Check. Sound design? Check. Digital audio? Check. Effects? Check. Marketing? Check. Live and DJ work? Check. Publishing? Check. Mastering? Check. Legal? Check. Creative motivation? Check. History? Check. Sound reinforcement? Check. DAWs and mixing and VST plugins and EQ and controllers and microphones and audio recording and sampling and…and…and? Check x10. It's all in there. I don't know why more people don't recommend this priceless resource. It's either because they see it as a secret and don't want anyone else to know about it or because they never read it because they don't like to read. Either way, buy it and read it. It's the only direct real shortcut that is legitimate to jump-starting your career in electronic music today. Period You can thank me later. ;)

Hi,I suggest this article:  I decided to write down some guidelines on how to make electronic music (although some of the following tips may apply to other musical genres as well, not just electronic music) covering such things as what hardware is required or recommended, what kind of music making software is needed, how to get a hang of different kind of electronic music styles, etc. There’s a lot of choices in hardware and software, countless of ways to do things in production wise and as many arguments and differing opinions as there are producers. In this article I try to point you to the right direction in electronic music production, mostly based on my own experience. A little info about myself is that electronic music production has been my longtime hobby for years and I’ve been creating music on such genres as trance, downtempo, ambient and experimental. Some of my songs has been released commercially through record labels and has also been used in a film project. Excuse my english, it’s my second language and not so perfect, but I hope you understand and find these guidelines useful and get your answer on how to make electronic music. Also, if you have any questions, opinions or improvements, feel free to leave a comment! Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) *ESSENTIAL* The digital audio workstation (or DAW) serves as your main beat making software and is the heart of your home studio. This is the program that you do everything in — sequence your instruments, mix and master your songs, and ideally, record vocals. My favorite DAW is hands-down Propellerhead Reason. I’ve been a long time user of Reason, and love how it’s low on CPU resources and virtually crash-free. I still haven’t found any other program that makes it as easy to bang out a quick beat — the workflow is simply ah-may-zing! Although you can’t use virtual instruments, I can definitely recommend this for beginners since everything you need is in the box. You no longer need a separate program to record vocals since version 6 introduced audio recording. Meanwhile, 6.5 introduced rack extensions (the Propellerhead answer to third-party VSTs) and the included sound bank is incredibly extensive. I use Propellerhead Reason as my main beat making program because not only is it a stable and flexible DAW that allows you to do whatever you want, but because it’s also bundled with great sound content. Not only that, but it’s sound design capabilities is beyond incredible. It gives you plenty of flexibility and a great deal of instruments to make your beats with. For most people (including me), it’s really all you need to start making beats on your computer. There are plenty of other options, but at the end of the day it’s more important that you learn the ins and outs of your DAW so you know how to do what you want to do. (While you may not have the money to purchase the full program right away, beginners would be happy to see that Reason has a little brother called Reason Essentials. When you’re starting out to make beats, there’s no better way to spend a hundred dollars. Just don’t waste your money or time on Dubturbo or Sonic Producer, LOL.)

I'm not an accomplished producer by any means, but here's my advice:  Don't get too caught up with which software / tools to use. There's no shame in starting with something inexpensive and user friendly like Garage Band, Reason or Ableton. You don't need Logic and hardware synths to make good music.I've heard accomplished producers (Cladue Von Stroke in particular) say that a great way to learn how to produce is to recreate your favorite tracks. This may sound boring and non-creative, but it teaches you how to make your music sound the way you want it to (the hardest part for me).A huge part of making electronic music (particularly dance music) is mastering (adjusting levels and eq'ing each instrument). A great way to do this is to keep another artist's track that you like on hand or even in your project. That way you can constantly compare so you remember what good music sounds like.Invest in some good studio monitors headphones or speakers. Listen to your tracks on a variety of audio systems.Finish tracks, release often and constantly seek feedback. A lot of people (myself included) tend to be overly perfectionist and have a ton of unfinished projects. I find I rarely return to these unfinished projects and don't learn nearly as much from them.Make sure to have fun! Don't stress about it or put pressure on yourself.

Okay. To start off, you're going to need a DAW (Digital Audio Workstation). The forerunners right now are FL Studio, Ableton, Cubase, and Logic. Your DAW is pretty much your map for the music you make. You drag your sounds into the DAW and it plays them in whatever sequence you want. There are many to choose from and they all do the same things, it's just the workflow is different for each one. Next you're going to need a synthesizers and effect VSTs. This is software that you will use to make the sounds that you hear in the song. Synthesizers use oscillators and wavetables to create the sounds you hear in all electronic music. In terms of synths, Serum by Xfer Records and Massive by Native Instruments are the biggest names in the sound design scene right now. For effects, you're gonna want different plugins for different sounds; so to start off I'd equip my self with a reverb, delay, distortion, equalizer, and stereo imager which should cover anything you'd need in the beginning stages of production. For reverb and delay, DAWs almost always come with effects for those so you don't really need external ones in the beginning. While all DAWs have an EQ built in, I'd highly recommend Fabfilter's Pro-Q2, as it allows you to do things many average EQs do not, like solo out the frequencies you are editing. For distortion, there's Ohmicide by Ohm Force, or Camel Crusher by Camel Audio. You'll have little use for a stereo imager in the beginning but it's good to learn about panning as you progress with your production. That's pretty much all the software you need for just starting off, but there's a lot more knowledge than you'd expect needed to really start improving. The top things I would suggest you start studying right from the beginning is: Sound Design Mixing Mastering Music Theory Sidechain Having knowledge of these will give you a big boost for someone just starting off, something I wish I'd known about when I'd just started. Lastly, you'll need a platform to release your music on. The #1 for up-and-coming producers right now is Soundcloud, where you can upload free of charge and get exposure to many big labels once your production knowledge has matured. Hope this helped! If you have any more questions totally hit me up on my soundcloud: D I Λ M I C Just make sure you say you came from Quora ^

There is a great wealth of technical information and pedagogical clues even on this thread lone, so the tools you need are mostly covered, but the real hurdle you'll have to face is how to keep the momentum, as making electronic music is often a solitary affair, even if it is club music. So how do you make music that invigorates you to make more music? That's what I'll speak to here: Try to foster the habit of listening to a variety of music, both actively and passively.  Especially when you listen to electronic music, start asking yourself why you like certain things about it, be it a particular sound or a feeling you get at a particular moment. Then think about how those sounds or that effect might be made, dissect what you hear.  Often an amazing sound is actually 2 or more combined. This is the mindset of a maker and I think everything else important follows from this.  You can have a lot of fun being creative by challenging yourself when you sit down to work on a track.  Try using a smaller palette/ less sounds than whatever you're used to. Try being minimal. Try being maximal. Try using sounds you find ugly.  The goal here is to learn and expand the range of what you can do. Figure out if you need some physicality to get motivated about your music. I couldn't do without an actual keyboard, a guitar, a bass and sometimes a sampler, I need something to hit and play. Maybe you don't need this, but it's something you should be aware of. Make songs and bounce them frequently, put them on an iPod or whatever you use, and constantly listen to and evaluate them in the context of the rest of your music. Keep making stuff and don't worry about the flaws unless you are actively trying to fix them, in which case, be fucking ruthless! Listen to the early examples of whatever sub-genre(s) of electronic music you like. It's usually awesome. You don't need another list of software, you need to figure out why you want to do this in the first place, and keep that motivation alive. For me, there is nothing like struggling with a track for a while and then finally feeling something amazing coming through. Getting the software is the easy part.

So, you are a classical pianist and wan to make some electronic music? Well, the easiest way to start is by getting a DAW for your computer. Which one specifically depends on two factors: a) what OS your computer has and b) your personal preference of the workflow. You can do just about everything with just about every DAW, just with differing ways to get it done, which is why I normally advice to download a bunch of demos of different DAWs, play around with them and then get the one that “feels” right. They are all rather complex and huge programs, mind, so you will need some time to really learn the one you choose. I’d start by actually reading the manual back and forth, playing around with it and using the internet. You’ll generally find tutorials for every DAW under the sun and if you get more knowledgeable you’ll also be able to adapt/“translate” tutorials for other DAWs—you’ll just have to keep at it and learn. Hardware-wise you actually should be OK with a decent computer if it isn’t too old. In fact, most likely you can just start with what you have if you have one. If not, you do want the strongest CPU you can get, a decent amount of RAM and as much Storage as possible. In regards to audio hardware you could get away with just using your on-board sound card at first—I did that for years—but since you are a classical pianist it would a shame not to make use of that, so you might actually want a decent audio interface coupled with a Midi-Keyboard. The Interface in this case mostly to reduce the latency—which your onboard will likely be horrible with—which will actually matter when you use a keyboard as over a certain threshold it will feel really awkward to play due to the delay between you pressing a key and the sound actually, well, sounding. Lastly, you also want a decent pair of as-linear-as-possible studio-headphones and/or studio-monitors. In case of the latter you also want some acoustic treatment for the room you work in—I am sure as a classical pianist you do know how different rooms can sound from each other and when producing music, be it electronic or not, those colorations don’t make it any easier to actually hear what you are doing. For knowledge regarding how to make the music, well, that is a bit more complicated. You mentioned you already know a lot of musical theory—which is helpful—but you will notice that you can—and in some cases must—ignore most of it. Electronic music often does not really care all that much for that and instead is more concerned with how different sounds work together. You’ll get a feel for that with time and likely you’ll also find your own sound pretty fast. Emulating others does help learning, of course, however, don’t forget to experiment on your own and just do what you want, don’t force yourself to have a certain sound when your natural sound goes in a different direction—you might actually end up making something completely different then you set out to do at first. Also helpful is reading up on how different synthesizer types work on a technical level, what the different things do an mean, what the different effects are and how they work on a technical and physical level… basically: be a sponge for all the knowledge you can get, even if it is very dry and technical. The understanding will help you using your gear a lot. The internet is your friend, of course. This point is also my personal measurement if someone actually cares for making electronic music or if they just blindly tinker around: someone who actually cares will basically be a nerd by necessity. You also want to read up on mixing and mastering: you find all kinds of tutorials online and talking with other people also can help a lot. Again, a lot of it will be surprisingly technical in nature—especially once you start learning what specific instruments use which frequency bands or what the different frequency bands actually do in context of music—but if one wants to make something like electronic music you’d assume one is aware that that is just part of the deal. Lastly: it helps to analyze a lot of (electronic) music. Not just listen to but actively analyzing, picking apart what each instrument does, how they work together, what timings the rhythm works on, etc. etc.—I’m sure you know what I mean. And from there it is… well, experimenting and just making music. There is a lot of theoretical knowledge you’ll need to learn, yes, but the fun part, actually making music, luckily is still often just 98% “experiment around until it works” and 2% “I’ve no clue how that works but it sounds neat (aka. “happy accidents”)” And don’t forget: your first hundred songs will be crap, but that is normal so don’t let yourself get dragged down by it if you just can’t get it sounding quite right yet. No master ever just fell out of the sky.

If you ask out of curiosity, I could elaborate a bit of history first. As a teacher myself in audio technologies, I always spend time explaining the long evolution of technology at the service of music.  It can be first traced to the 13th century with al-Jazari, who invented the first robot music, an automaton that was meant to entertain guests. Even then, it was about having automatic machine where a third party would be creating music instead of humans. The idea of electronic, or technological music, takes interests in various approaches: Reproducing/imitating sound.Facilitating and democratizing the art of music.Having the highest level of technology as music instruments.Different important milestones: Invention of electrical amplifications, the beginning of amplified sound. (1906)Theremin and other electronic playable machines.(1920)Musique Concrète/Electroacoustics, who used tapes as a creative medium (and more).First synthesizers, who, with oscillators, can replicate sounds. (1970's)Computer music.I know this might be a bit confusing but I can also just send you to a Youtube, learn how to use a DAW like Ableton Live (one of the most intuitive and easy to learn as well as, so many tutorials online) but one important thing I find, is to know a bit of the origins of what a simple software can do for you. You'll be soon using various techniques to create music entirely made by your computer, your new assistant. You can quickly understand how a DAW works, but the techniques can be discussed for hours and asking how electronic is created, can quickly become intricate, complicated, abstract, surreal and slightly overwhelming. Why? Electronic music of today will be defined into various categories: Sound design. Creating your own sounds, textures, from sound synthesis, using oscillators.Programming. You can dig at the core of your compute and use audio-language related envronment such as MAX/MSP. You'll need to understand programming in general and have a lot of time to produce your first bleeps.Composing/sequencing. Using loops or your own sounds, to create a narrative story.Sampling. Using recorded sounds or found sounds and manipulate them.So, it's a really absorbing hobby. And asking to describe how to do it, also comes from a perspective. As a music producer, I really work on creating from scratch, my own synthesizers (can take a few weeks) in a software named Reaktor, then will spend time running it through external effects, record everything in a DAW then assemble everything in Ableton Live. Making a song can take a lot of time.  Some other producers feel content with buying loops and then playing with them. To each its own, there's no best or real way to make music. But funny thing is, in the 90's, so many people were mocking me about making electronic music, thinking it was really easy. Nowadays, I invite whoever thinks it's easy to sit by myself for an evening of production. I swear, no one ever thinks its easy after seeing me work!

There are various approaches to producing electronic music, none of them exclusive. Generally speaking, you have the hardware approach and the software approach. Hardware involves various synths, drum machines, groove boxes, MIDI controllers, etc. The software approach involves using a computer with the proper specs, a DAW (digital audio workstation) and various other pieces of software, often plugins such as VSTs, that enable other functionality, effects and instrumentation.  Often, the two approaches are combined, and there have been many debates over the pros and cons of each approach. The truth is that the approach that works for you and makes you happy is the only one that matters. Having said this, it is important to keep things simple at the beginning. I have seen others quit due to the fact that they expected too much right away, or had too much gear, or advanced gear beyond their understanding, and they became frustrated and quit.  What you want to do is begin learning the basics of bars and measures, tempo and beats. Learn how to make a single rhythm pattern, then try adding a bassline to it. Create a similar pattern and then chain the two together. These types of simple exercises will gradually enable you to become familiar with the larger DAW environment, or with whatever hardware you are using. This is basically how you get started. Don't spend too much money at first. Also, don't just buy what your favorite artist has without going to a music store and playing with it first. Watch Youtube videos with various pieces of gear/software. You also want to remember that being a gear-hog and being a music producer are two different things. You don't need tons of gear or even expensive gear. In fact, lots of gear that is considered boutique and high-end is actually less capable than older gear you can get for less money. For example, don't get sucked into buying stuff like Elektron gear unless you already know that is the workflow you want. While you practice the basics, you are going to come across the concept of mixing. This is very important and can't be learned overnight. When you have spare time, watch some videos about using EQ properly on each instrument, as this will determine the clarity and true energy of your mix. Many novices make the mistake of believing that big awesome sounds (the kind companies use to sell VST synths) are what you want. In reality, however, those large sounds eat up your frequency bandwidth. What you really want to do is learn how smaller sounds, controlled with EQ, compression, the stereo field, etc., combine to create one large, clean mix.  Once you understand the basics, go back to your favorite tunes and study them. Listen to the structures they use, and try to understand the flow of energy. Understand that when you produce a track, it's not just about the notes and the sounds, but the energy, and also the production technique. Ask yourself what the audience needs to hear, and then figure out how to accomplish that without compromising your own artistic integrity. Have fun and good luck!

There is no single right answer to this question. It's sort of like asking "what is the best way to learn to paint like Picasso?" Whilst one certainly can learn to become a competent painter through practice and lessons, there is no fixed way to become a masterful artist. The same applies with music, in my opinion. With regards to electronic music specifically, there are two major components in the equation. One is audio engineering, which you can learn about through courses and by reading online, but also requires a tremendous amount of practice and ear training. Most modern electronic music employs extensive use of advanced audio engineering techniques. At a basic level, it is critical to gain a deep understanding of equalization (EQ) and compression. These are what enable electronic music producers to mix together so many different sounds across a wide frequency spectrum without ending up with a "muddy" sound. The other half of electronic music is the actual music. It's very easy to create derivative, uncreative electronic music. Ultimately, creating high quality electronic music requires true musicianship in the artistic sense. Electronic music also presents a unique set of musical challenges, in that there are very few timbral restrictions placed on the composer (i.e. you do not have a fixed set of instruments or sounds to work with). In my opinion, the best way to get started is to simply dive in and start experimenting on your own. The easiest way to do this is with software. There are many freeware programs available, and many of the large software companies offer free trials. Entire websites are devoted to covering audio production gear (both software and hardware). The heart of any modern studio setup tends to be a DAW (digital audio workstation). Many electronic music producers are currently using Ableton Live, as its workflow is built around manipulating loops. Other common DAWs are Apple Logic, Cakewalk SONAR, Steinberg Cubase, MOTU Digital Performer and Digidesign Pro Tools.

My three essential rules for mastering any craft, in ascending order of importance: FeedbackInputPractice To explain: Practice: you need to do something to get better at it. A lot. As in, an hour or two per day, almost every day, for years. In "The Tipping Point", he made a pretty good case for 10,000 hours being the amount of practice it takes to master a skillset. Want to be a pro baseball player? Play a lot of baseball. Famous author? Write oodles of novels. Electronic musician? Log hours fiddling in DAWs. Input: you can NOT become a great writer without reading tons of books. You can't direct great movies without watching one or two. Listen to lots of tunes. I'm hoping though that if you want to be a musician, you're already doing this. Feedback: get some constructive criticism from people qualified to give it. Otherwise you could waste serious time going down wrong roads. Also get opinions from less-informed fans of your genre. Remember the rule of thumb for fan feedback: they'll always know when there's a problem, they'll never know what the problem is. Use uneducated fan feedback to locate rough patches, use learned feedback to fix them. And listen to all feedback, but don't automatically swallow it--bad advice exists; that's why it's important to get a large volume of feedback, to minimize damage from individual pieces of bum advice. So that's it, my three essentials to master any craft. I don't have any credentials to flash here, as I am not a professional DJ (although people have danced to my beats-and-blips), but fuck it, I'll go ahead and vouch for my rules anyway. [edit: inserted omitted word and tweaked to improve flow]

There is a multitude of ways you can start making electronic music, I'll try and break it down super simply. Computer & DAW - if you have a Mac, I would highly recommend purchasing “Logic Pro X”. I am biased because I use this Digital Audio Workstation, however arguments for also include its price, beginner friendly interface, and funnily enough the logicality of the way it works! Lots of people recommend Ableton Live too, so download the demo version of that as well as Garage Band (Logic’s little brother) and see which one works for your brain the best. If you don't have a Mac, Ableton will be more suitable and or other programs like Reason, FL Studio and Cubase… do some research in to these!DAW Experience - have you ever used a music program before? The internet is jam packed full of tutorials for all of these programs. No matter where you are in the process, there is an unlimited resource of how to’s all over YouTube and forums etc. The web is one your most vital tools. (Try MusicTechHelpGuy for a literal step by step Logic Pro X breakdown)Studio Monitors - integral to creating music that is going to be suitable on all sound systems is purchasing a set of studio monitors. Unlike your car stereo or boom box at home, there is no Equalisation or Compression built in - it's as pure as it can sound. There are people who’ll be able to put that in much more specific terms than me but this is super vital. They can go cheap, or they can go outrageously expensive!MIDI Keyboard - this is the most logical way to start “making sounds”. Since you're a pianist I suggest getting a larger midi keyboard - they're very cheap, eBay has tonnes. Have a USB 2.0 cord (like a printer USB) ready, plug it in, select a track in your DAW, choose a software synth or instrument or piano or drum… the world is literally now your oyster.These are what I believe to be the fundamentals of beginning to produce electronic music, and there's always a way to do it on the cheaper side if budget is a problem. If you're interested in recording vocals or live instruments, purchase an audio interface & a decent condenser microphone. Use the internet to find out about products through forums, there will always be enough information to make an informed decision. Good luck in your creative endeavours!

Been playing piano since 9, composing and producing since middle school. Honestly, get a cheap Yamaha keyboard and start playing around with sounds. Also take note of your favorite music. You want to develop your style and be childlike before you start learning the structural stuff. Don't worry about technique. After a few months, get some weekly lessons in piano, guitar, or whatever you like(I'd say piano!) . Keep playing around on the side, but now you'll have a bit more music knowledge. You'll know basic music theory after taking lessons, but after a few months of lessons take a short music theory course online or in school where you'll learn more about chords, key signatures, etc. This is the fun part bc now you can take all the stuff youve been playing with to a higher level. Now it's time for production. Learn how to arrange basic tracks or beats from start to finish. I started with a program called Anvil Studios for PC years ago. MuLab is also cool(for Mac). If you have money to spend, buy FL Studio or Ableton. After, you'll get into instrumentation and choosing the right sounds. Don't worry too much about mixing and effects . Your main focus should be creating something musically sound. There are many places to download or purchase sound loops or vocal samples online. Sone people stop here and send their tracks over to a mixing/mastering engineer (who have MANY years of experience) and it’s usually not advised to master your own tracks. If you want to learn mixing, it's a lot of work but doable if you really want to do it. You can find tutorials on all of these but the key is to be as unrestrained as possible. Anything you make can become a masterpiece. I burned out and took a break for years because I was too focused on doing everything “"correctly.” It's just Art.

When I was young in 70s I built an 8-steps 1 note sequencer. That was before MIDI. Now is the good time to start! There are thousands of EM styles. A public is prepared to listen to anything - from Noise to Trance. There are styles which integrate acoustical sources as vocal or any mic signal and ones are generated completely within computer. So, choosing a style - is, perhaps, Task #1. Personally, I like the idea to start from… mobile. Choose any app, try dozens, find what you like. A modern mobile phone is incredibly powerful beast. It can record / transform / generate sounds, but then - compose / edit / publish your compositions. If you want to start from the middle of the road, invest into any USB sound interface for your computer. Any budget package ($200–$300) consists of an interface and software. You will start definitely in the good form. Another, Top Dream $$$ Start: to become an analogist! Learn everything Moog and others, produces, learn basic with a real analog ADSR, Filters, VCO’s. ‘Writing electronic music’ means writing music. Learn to play some acoustical instrument - guitar, piano, violin. Learn to write music - melody and harmony. Probably, that is Task #0. Mobile is easy and feature rich. Analog is expensive, but a solid platform for years. DAW is for everything.

Assuming you are new music production. Follow this guide and you will avoid years of frustration. Take 10 of your current favorite tracks. They must have been released in the last 6 months and by a known label in your genre. Ideally you know or can figure out the bpm and key. Import the first track into your DAW. Now create empty tracks and label them Kick, Bass, Percussion, Synth, Pad, Effect, etc. In each of these tracks create a blank MIDI region and map out the track sound by sound. So if you here the kick for 8 bars you will have a corresponding 8 bar blank MIDI region labeled “Kick”. If the kick drops out for 4 bars leave that part of the track blank. Repeat this for all the main sounds you can hear. You don’t have to get too detailed for this first exercise. By the end you should have a basic outline/template. Why is a template important? DJs, labels, listeners look for familiarity. In dance music much of that will come through track structure - intro, break, drop, bridge, outro. Structure also will give you a roadmap to complete a track. Now repeat this for the other 9 tracks. But each time get more detailed. Add a track for snare rolls, filtered percussion, fading synths, etc. By the end of the exercises you should have 10 templates. Study them and look for patterns. Don’t make an original track yet. Use these 10 templates and remix 10 of your favorite tracks. Stick to the template. Don't vary. Don't play with the melody. Don’t veer off into making an original. Remix only at this point. Once you’ve completed these 10 remixes you are now ready to start learning more about mixing techniques, choosing plugins, sound design and so on. It will take time. But if you dedicate yourself you’ll be light years ahead of every other bedroom producer out there. All the best.

You need proper software and knowlage For software recommendation i would give you this: Digital Beat Making Software  and the rest you need to : Learn the basics of music Now I’m in no doubt that some of you reading this have experience from playing instruments or being a vocalist so this step may not be relevant. If thats you. Skip this step and read the other steps because they ARE relevant. Now if you’ve never made music or played and instrument you may feel completely confused about where to start, but everyone starts somewhere. So I’d do your research and learn about these basics bullet points: – Learn what a Beat & Bar is (not a place where you go and get drunk). – Learn what a time signature is.– Learn about BPM (Beats Per Minute) View a tutorial that covers all of the above – Learn the difference between major and minor keys. – View tutorial – Learn what KEY is and means. – View tutorial– Learn an instrument, I highly recommend learning to play the piano. Because if you’re going to be a producer. You’ll be using the keyboard/piano layout a lot. – View tutorial – Learn basic chords and chord sequences. – View tutorial Now learning all of the above may take a while and some of the tutorials may be a bit long winded. But If you know the basics of all the above you’ll have a massive advantage when it comes to producing your own electronic dance music, why? Because you’ll have the understanding of how songs work and how they’re structured. This gives you an amazing starting point. Enjoy -Allen

I decided to write down some guidelines on how to make electronic music (although some of the following tips may apply to other musical genres as well, not just electronic music) covering such things as what hardware is required or recommended, what kind of music making software is needed, how to get a hang of different kind of electronic music styles, etc. There’s a lot of choices in hardware and software, countless of ways to do things in production wise and as many arguments and differing opinions as there are producers. In this article I try to point you to the right direction in electronic music production, mostly based on my own experience. A little info about myself is that electronic music production has been my longtime hobby for years and I’ve been creating music on such genres as trance, downtempo, ambient and experimental. Some of my songs has been released commercially through record labels and has also been used in a film project. Excuse my english, it’s my second language and not so perfect, but I hope you understand and find these guidelines useful and get your answer on how to make electronic music. Also, if you have any questions, opinions or improvements, feel free to leave a comment! Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) *ESSENTIAL* The digital audio workstation (or DAW) serves as your main beat making software and is the heart of your home studio. This is the program that you do everything in — sequence your instruments, mix and master your songs, and ideally, record vocals. My favorite DAW is hands-down Propellerhead Reason. I’ve been a long time user of Reason, and love how it’s low on CPU resources and virtually crash-free. I still haven’t found any other program that makes it as easy to bang out a quick beat — the workflow is simply ah-may-zing! Although you can’t use virtual instruments, I can definitely recommend this for beginners since everything you need is in the box. You no longer need a separate program to record vocals since version 6 introduced audio recording. Meanwhile, 6.5 introduced rack extensions (the Propellerhead answer to third-party VSTs) and the included sound bank is incredibly extensive. I use Propellerhead Reason as my main beat making program because not only is it a stable and flexible DAW that allows you to do whatever you want, but because it’s also bundled with great sound content. Not only that, but it’s sound design capabilities is beyond incredible. It gives you plenty of flexibility and a great deal of instruments to make your beats with. For most people (including me), it’s really all you need to start making beats on your computer. There are plenty of other options, but at the end of the day it’s more important that you learn the ins and outs of your DAW so you know how to do what you want to do. (While you may not have the money to purchase the full program right away, beginners would be happy to see that Reason has a little brother called Reason Essentials. When you’re starting out to make beats, there’s no better way to spend a hundred dollars. Just don’t waste your money or time on Dubturbo or Sonic Producer, LOL.)

Start by focusing not exclusively electronic music, but develop your general musical skills (especially your hearing) and study the BASICS of audio engineering extensively. Point 1 from Peter’s answer is absolutely spot on. It makes me smile these days when well-meaning guys just getting into the game ask me on end about which DAW is best or which plugin suites they should buy. Here’s the truth: All DAWs worth their salt do EXACTLY the same thing (off the top of my head I’d recommend Pro Tools, Logic, Sonar, Cubase, Studio One, FL Studio, Ableton, Reason, Bitwig or Reaper to name a few). It’s true that professionals generally have a preference but that’s mostly down to workflow; for instance I like logic a lot but because I mostly work in pro tools the keyboard shortcuts for PT are second nature to me. When I have to use Logic, guess what, they don’t work :) and that slows me down, but that doesn’t mean either DAW is better or worse. Also the majority of DAWs come with free plugins which I could (and HAVE, btw) used exclusively to mix tracks for commercial release without any expensive Waves, NI, UAD, Soundtoys or whatever extras. You don’t need them to get professional results, and until you know how to use each and every single one of the plugins that comes with your DAW, buying plugins is a waste of money that could be put to better use, like on acoustic treatment for your room. First thing first: pick a DAW that you like the look of and learn it back to front. Learn what EQ is, and how to use it. Learn about compression, and how to use it. Learn about using reverb/delays effectively. Learn these things back to front, and download one of the many apps available that test your knowledge of frequencies. Train your ears, listen to lots of different types of music, and pick up a basic music theory manual. If you don’t play piano/keys, grab a beginner’s book on that too because keyboard skills are ESSENTIAL especially for electronic music production. Next: I know it’s tempting to blow money on super awesome speakers, but they’re next to useless if your room’s acoustics are problematic. Research stuff like standing waves, room modes etc and get yourself some materials to treat it. Headphones might seem like an easy way out of this but unfortunately even the best headphones in the world aren’t going to give you a realistic idea of how your bass levels will respond on a proper system. Reason: Sub/Bass frequencies require BIG woofers to reproduce them properly. Headphones = too small. If it comes down to a choice between monitors and acoustics, choose acoustics every time. Get yourself a decent MIDI controller keyboard (I like AKAI personally), some reasonably priced headphones for checking small details that get lost on monitors (I recommend something like Sennheiser 280s to start off with) and have at it. Oh, and I’m just assuming you already have an audio interface - if not, Focusrite make very reliable and high quality kit for a reasonable price. I could go on forever, but since your question is ‘how do I start?’ I’ll leave it there for now. Hope that helps, good luck and if you have any more questions don’t hesitate to get in touch directly. All the best, Benedict

A2A Well, that’s a very broad question which there is no unilateral answer to. It is in fact possible to produce at least instrumentals on a Macbook alone. Your starting point is a DAW (digital audio workstation) such as Ableton, Logic, Cubase etc. The choice depends on your preference on how to produce (and your budget). DAWs like Logic and Cubase are more rooted in the “old school” methods of multitrack recording and mixing whereas Ableton and Reason have a different architecture and slightly more oriented towards DJs than musicians. In any case, most DAWs come with a standard selection of quite useable AU plugins, with virtual instruments such as drum machine, sampler, synths, e-piano plus some decent FX like compression, delay and reverb. It should be enough for you to get started. For starters you can actually use the keyboard on your Mac for recording simple chords and bass lines and your mouse for note by note input. I would however suggest to get a USB controller keyboard with pads for recording the drum tracks. Examples: Novation Impulse, M-Audio Oxygen, Akai MPK etc. The right choice depends on your preferences and your budget. The above is enough to start producing inside the Mac in premix quality. Don’t expect tunes in pro quality ready to be released though as long as you don’t have proper monitoring which should be as neutral as possible. There is a whole science around monitoring, including finding the right acoustic environment/treatment etc… I could write pages if I had time. The next step (basically at the same time as all of the above) would be to get a pair of active nearfield monitors. The same applies here in terms of budget and preference. Btw KRK have some very decent and reasonably priced ones. Then since the headphone output of the Macbook is far from being optimised for driving studio monitors, one day you will look into audio interfaces with a decent preamp for microphone recordings in case you want to add vocals to your creations. I don’t know about specific online courses for electronic music but there are plenty of tutorials on Youtube. Like myself, most electronic producers are autodidacts. After learning the basics experimenting is the key. Speaking for myself I was lucky enough to grow up together with the first hardware synths and drummies in the pre-MIDI era. Then came MIDI and I was hooked. With the little I could afford back in the 80s I learned about synth and drum programming out of the box with no instructions whatsoever. I think the less gear you have in the beginning the faster you will get familiar with the basics and once you get the hang of it it will become a natural progression. The main thing is enthusiasm and plenty of good ideas and inspiration. Get funky! Edit - here’s an example for Logic X (which is what I use)

Actually, there is a fantastic online university for electronic musicians that takes you from the begining stages.  It's called Sonic Academy and the videos teach you genre specific tips, tips about recording, using compression, reverb, etc.  I've watched a lot of tutorials and these are some of the most helpful because of the genre specific tips.  It does cost, but some of the videos are free. They actually have a video that teaches you some of the techniques of JUSTICE and Daft Punk.  I watched this particular video and followed along and made a pretty great crunchy bassline.  I was very happy with it.www.SonicAcademy.comLink here: http://www.sonicacademy.com/Producer/Course//How_to_Make_French_House_with_Reason_4_-_Justice.cid2717  For a lot of the videos these use specific software like Reason, Ableton, Logic or Cubase.  These are, of course, the most popular software for making electronic music.  I switched from Cubase to Ableton because of how easy it is to start making music.  The aspects I like most about Ableton from the beginner perspective, are the tutorials and the the help box at the bottom left of the screen.  You can scroll over anything and learn what it does.  If you have a Mac, I would also suggest Logic.  You can download demos of most of these software on the website.

You find the right tools, of course.  I'm a firm believer in making do with what you have (Read my blog post: Art Now: Do Something With What You Have), so the right tools are the ones already in front of you. They're the apps already in your computer, or they're free & open sourced software [FOSS] that you can download.  They're free apps you can download for your mobile device too.  But before you go on a product hunt, figure out what your objectives are (e.g.  to make tracks that people dance? to create audio candy for headphone use? to make digital music for a game/movie/presentation? to express your inner Aphex Twin?)  Your objectives will dictate what kind/genre of electronic music you should study. And by study, I mean, actively listening for song structure, for song parts, for instrumentation, for musical arrangements.  The rest, as they say, is a hodgepodge of YouTube tutorials, how-to blog posts, and musician forums.  Good luck!

There has never been a better time to start creating your own music and doing so on a limited budget. Honestly it doesn’t take much to start. You’ll need a computer and some basic software and headphones. If you want to track any acoustic or live instruments/voice, you’ll need an audio interface and a microphone. But if you use want to start with just basic programming of drums and synths, you can do it all “in the box” with computer, software and headphones. I’m a Cubase guy, but for the money I love the program Logic for recording music. It is a pro system, relatively inexpensive, and has great software synths and processing effects included. And there are tons of tutorials online to get you from the basics and beyond. If you own a mac, you get Garageband for free, and that is a great recording system to start out with and grow into Logic. But whatever you decide, just know that there are so many great how-to videos out there to show you how to use your recording software, how to build sounds with synth and drum software and how to bring those sounds together into a full song. The great thing about making music is that, unlike so many industries, it has just gotten cheaper to do over the years. I have a pretty huge setup now, but I started on some pretty humble gear. And I made a lot of money using that gear. So, it really comes down to creativity and basic tools. Here’s a look at the little setup I used to build songs that started my career with Selena Gomez and Miley Cyrus:

So, let’s see what all you’ll have to learn. Music TheoryIt’s quite necessary to learn music theory in order to produce music. Learning a basic instrument would be alright. Deep knowledge of Genres. (At least the genre you’re wanting to produce.)You should be through with the genre. Only then you’ll be able to explore further and create something original. Digital Audio Workstations or DAWsThe thing happens here. DAWs are nothing but software which help you produce music. They might seem extremely complex at start but you’ll get used to it. Sound DesignLearning the way of sound propagation will surely help you to play with the sound and make something efficient. MarketingWhat’s the fun if nobody listen to your music? Marketing and Disseminating is very essential. The best tactics of marketing will help you grow more popularly. Mixing and MasteringIt's the most important aspect if you want your sound to be as good as the pros, and it can be the difference between landing a release on a label or not. Start learning this early as it is one of the hardest and most important skills to master. TutorialsKeep watching them, anywhere, anytime. They’re so helpful! Have a query? YouTube’s there to help you. Yes, your utter determination towards the goal is required too. You might lose a lot of things during this journey, but it’ll be worth it. PS: This one’s not to discourage you, but just to inform you. It will take roughly 3 — 6 years for you to start getting noticed, give or take a few. Good Luck! Thanks to Oliver Presta for the Edit.

You need proper software and knowlage For software recommendation i would give you this: Digital Beat Making Software  and the rest you need to : Learn the basics of music Now I’m in no doubt that some of you reading this have experience from playing instruments or being a vocalist so this step may not be relevant. If thats you. Skip this step and read the other steps because they ARE relevant. Now if you’ve never made music or played and instrument you may feel completely confused about where to start, but everyone starts somewhere. So I’d do your research and learn about these basics bullet points: – Learn what a Beat & Bar is (not a place where you go and get drunk). – Learn what a time signature is.– Learn about BPM (Beats Per Minute) View a tutorial that covers all of the above – Learn the difference between major and minor keys. – View tutorial – Learn what KEY is and means. – View tutorial– Learn an instrument, I highly recommend learning to play the piano. Because if you’re going to be a producer. You’ll be using the keyboard/piano layout a lot. – View tutorial – Learn basic chords and chord sequences. – View tutorial Now learning all of the above may take a while and some of the tutorials may be a bit long winded. But If you know the basics of all the above you’ll have a massive advantage when it comes to producing your own electronic dance music, why? Because you’ll have the understanding of how songs work and how they’re structured. This gives you an amazing starting point. Enjoy -Frank

Hi, Thanks for A2A! So, you want to know how to produce music, more specifically - Electronic music. Well, it is time to get real in the sham world. Follow the below tips from expert music instructors & industry veterans; Know your instrument Do you really play because you want the attention? Or, do you play because you feel the passion for this noble art? If the latter is your reason, you ought to know your instrument in & out. Be it an electronic organ, drum machine or a synthesizer, feel the instrument & its immense power to master it. Learn from the experts Qualified experts and musicians with real credentials can teach you the right principles of producing lovable music. If you really want to learn how to produce electronic music, then you can enrol in this 5-day course with IO Music Acaddemy. This is not just a highly effective course, but a chance to collaborate with real musicians for real production. Hope the answer helps!

Well let me say first of all that when I started producing I was going for a denser sound with my beats but there’s a reason why EDM is where most people start from. EDM is an art form that simply requires a kick, any kick. The best part about this is the fact that all beats must have a theme.   Whether it is dubstep, trance, future bass or the recent tropical wave, the beauty of electronic is the vastness of its genre. I started with FL and went on to download packs from all over the internet. I discovered later that it wasn’t the amount of samples you had but the ability you have in composing them together to create a rhythm. When you begin, if you are already good in the keyboard find a 5-sec long piano roll and fit it at the beginning, if not, find a key that you like and play around it till you have that 5-sec roll Note: It mustn’t be 5-secs, Martin and Axwell have been known to use almost 10-secs of funny instruments like the banjo, lead guitar etc. NB: This layout is just an example, please, don’t limit your creativity, that is the whole point of electronic, EXPERIMENT!!!! So, next, repeat the piano roll with a kick and generate a synth alongside the entire pattern  Now, get ready for the good part Repeat this pattern again for some time (as it suits you) then begin to enter the bass drop build up     Will it be good on the first try? I doubt it but at least you can begin to understand what you want from the track so bear with me. I’m about to explain what I have learnt from the 2008 - 2017 EDM sub-niches Future Bass : This niche differs from regular EDM due to the lighter synths involved. This genre would be very noisy if not for the singular rule that limits the number of patterns applied to 5. Examples of this include Light by San Holo Dubstep : This was the most common form of EDM on the market when the genre first surfaced. It is so called because of its highly-anticipated bass drop and its use of excessive reverb and heavy synths.Trance: Out of a more compressed, needy electronic sound came Trance. This niche is originally House but, for lack of better names for the niche and since, Kygo sounds nothing like Guetta, we have trance.Tropical Wave: When it comes to this niche, many have said that this can’t possible have evolved from EDM well, it’s true. Dance music, which is essentially EDM and influences from synth-pop to jazz and more frequently reggaeton has built an empire around this analogy.If you are a new producer trying to get your hands dirty with some simple production tutorials try How To Make A Powerful EDM Track - FL Beat Tutorials and don’t forget to export in the highest audio quality your computer can process GOOD LUCK PLAYING!!!

BE ORIGINAL! If you want music thag sounds like NOBODY elses then yoh need to SAMPLE everything you can get your hands on that makes sound, including yourself.. (A) Sample your own voice (every persons voice is 100% unique, you don't even need to be able to sing to say “Oooooooo” and sample tha, then fine tune the pitch so it's in key with your arrnagement and then play a whole SYMPHONY from just that, it will sound completely unique! (B) Buy some analog hardware, a good analog synth will make the music process fun and will double as a midi controller and keybaord! (C) Buy NI Maschine and learn how to use the sampler in that, it's the bizz (D) REALLY Listen to your favorite songs and learn how they have made the Chorus/Verse/bridge song structure and try to replicate that structure in your own song. (E) Be creative. Take an existing drum loop and try to re-create each sound from the kit by sampling just your voice, listen to how original it sounds! (F) Go out into nature with a portable recorder and sample every sound you find, then make a song out of samples from that. (G) Make the lead melody FIRST, make it catchy. Then build your entire song around that. (H) Hang out with Tiesto  Don't give up  www.damienosborne.com

There are multiple software out there that allow to create electronic music with infinite possibilities. These are called DAWs, Digital Audio Workstations. Examples are Cubase, Logic, Studio one, Protools and many more If you are a musician already (guitarist, bassist, keyboard player), and you know the basics on how hardware gear works (amps, effect pedals, effects racks), I personally would recommend Propellerhead Reason. It is very intuitive and gets you started very quickly. and for electronic styles, Reason is recognized as being the top! Very recently I tried myself at creating a video course that is ideal for guys or gals that want to give a shot at producing music with Reason.

Buy a digital audio workstation like fl studio, logic, ableton live or reason and others. Other equipment you'll need are midi keyboard, speakers, and headphones. To learn how to do make music start by recreating your favorite songs as a way of practice to learn your daw and how to make full songs. When your comfortable remaking songs start experimenting with your own ideas. Take your time and learn how to make good tracks. Don't be afraid to share your work with others as this will help you grow.

Well you only need a computer. Everything else is just add-ons. You need a DAW (Digital Audio Workstation) on your computer, and you're good to go. You don't need any fancy synths, MIDI controllers, speakers and so on. I started out using the Apple Earpods from my iPhone.  Just keep on making music. Your first project ain't going to sound good. Quite the opposite, really. But if you are continuing to make tracks, it will eventually sound good.  As time goes by, you can start to invest in VST's, speakers and MIDI controllers. But don't think you need them to start producing. All you need is a computer and determination.

Well, first of all, you need a computer, preferably one with very good or excellent performance specs, like a huge amount of RAM, and a high-end processor, and a high-end graphics card. Also, you need to invest in software to make the music. You can use Fruity Loops as a starting point program, since it is free, and is functional enough to start with. You also have to have a very well-made knowledge base for how to create it. Once you have all that down, then you can start the actual making music part. Without a computer, you really can’t do much of anything with it. Now, the type of operating system you use is solely up to personal preference. I’ve heard that many artists/musicians use Macs, but you can also use Windows PCs for that too. It just depends on what you are accustomed to using. I prefer Windows, because it is what I have used since I was three years old. So, it is what I am accustomed to using. But, you may prefer to use a Mac computer. Or, you may even prefer Linux. It is totally up to your personal preference. I wish you the best of luck in your endeavors. Thank you for reading this answer.

Well you need either instruments or software or both. I recommend sonic foundry acid as a beginner platform for putting loops on top of each other in a basic sequencer. Its free but you pay around £50 for the full version. Other programs such as fruity loops are more complicated and theres programs like ableton live or cubase which are even more complicated. Youll need a computer with low latency (ie high amount of RAM) and low noise - fans in normal computers can interfere with recording. You will also need a decent sound card and possibly an interface for whatever instrument you play. If you dont already write music start listening to how it is formed. The drums, the bass, synth, lead, rhythm etc and how it hangs together. Start a basic track by using drums then adding layers to create somethkng. Collect as many samples as you can and these can be used as patches, loops or manipulated through midi keyboard or other software to add depth to your tracks. Find others that do it and speak to them. Acid has a community platform. Most cproducers are on soundcloud. There are production courses you can attend. Enjoy and good luck.

There a only few tools you need to actually produce electronic music, namely a DAW, which is a software program to edit, record, arrange and mix music on your computer. The first step would be getting a free or trial version of a DAW and seeing how you like it. Having a friend show you a few tricks is helpful too! If you get the music production bug, check out my post on what gear you’ll need to build a home studio - including audio interfaces, MIDI controllers and studio monitors on a budget. Hope this helps! Getting Started: How to Make Electronic Music

Well start from free software such as cubase (for desktop) or garageband for i-phones or demo version of FL or Ableton. Also to make sure good end result download free vst’s such as U-he Zebra, diva, etc. Now work on your production skills such as rythm making, systhesis by watching youtube tutorials and start creating your own music. Next comes, mixing and mastering. Before releasing anything on the internet , you need to mix and master your music. Apply mixing and mastering ticks to your track and take feedback from other producers who are experienced. Then comes the release(wooh) and start working on your skills again.

Well, i personally recommend OpenMPT (modern music tracker-available for free) and Synth1 (best free VSTi plugin you can get) for making electronic music. With OpenMPT you can create music similiar to how elecronic composers used to do it in the Amiga and DOS times, and save them in old (but well supported) module formats (MOD,S3M,XM,IT), which act like MIDI files, but have there samples, acting as instruments, integrated inside the file. Another seqencer/tracker i would recommend for creating electronic music is Renoise (low cost and well supported). For drum packs, they can be created using an VSTi inside an DAW (i usualy use BasicBat on OpenMPT), or get them from an wepside housing them, like kb6 (most drum packs are for free but for some, you have to donate). One thing, what kind of electronic music? There are several genres (these days Pop, Disco, Hip-Hop, Trance, Jungle, Bass and Drum, even New Age and so on...), so it may not sound the same. Just make your music the way it fits your musical style.

If you mean edm/deep house/techno trance etc… then I suggest listening to ALOT of electronic music and not limiting yourself to that genre only but listening to other genre's to expend your taste in music and also to figure what instruments may go with your taste of electro music. After you get a feel of how the songs sound then move on to start producing music with mobile apps like Magix music maker then move to fruit loops studio and start producing music on there. I just overly simplified what you should aim on doing, this process can take years to do.

The best way for a beginner make electronic music is to download a free ‘soft synth’ (like Bristol) and use your computers keyboard as a midi controller (you can use ‘PAVU’ to record the sound through Audacity) OR buy a cheap 25 key Midi controller like an Akai and use the free DAW that comes with it and start recording and try using a piano roll to compose your electronic music - it is really fun and rewarding.

First, learn to play good music.  I find that most electronic music suffers from a surplus of technology and a lack of musical talent.  The electronics should just compliment the composition, not be a substitute for it. So, pick up some instruments (not just a midi keyboard) and learn to play keys, guitars, and other instruments.   Then you start on a whole new adventure: learning to arrange, produce, and engineer the music.  It takes years to do well. Good luck.

1)  Have a day job.  This is not an inexpensive pursuit, when done properly. 2)  Be friendly, and willing to learn and take criticism. 3)  Read articles.  Electronic musicians love to talk about their gear, software, and techniques.  Learn from this. 4)  Find others making the same sort of music, and beg them to teach whatever they're willing. 5)  Be patient, and keep making friends.  You'll need every one of them if you want your music to Go Anywhere. Good luck!

Practice. Practice all you can. Whatever you can get your hands on. Originality. Be original. Don’t try too hard to sound like anyone else. Let it flow. Like any other form of art, let it come out from you and not anyone else. Learn. Read. Study. Sound design, EQ, Compression, Arrangement. Be creative. If it sounds awesome to you, chances are that it will sound awesome to a majority of other people. Be persistent in your endeavours.

The smallest n least way i should suggest you.. see dear there are many people out there in industry producing loads of music..dont think that you want to become like them and start producing now onwards.. the fact is music should come from the bottom of your heart you should actually feel it. becuse there are many people around who are just making music and producing becuse they just need the life of an artist. be the one dont force yourself others do so you should. firstly stay calm and ask a que to urself best luck buddy\U0001f44d

Software, you need sequencing software. I think Computer Music magazine (you can get it at any Barnes and Noble) it comes with a disc with tons of free Audio Production software. Get on YouTube, learn to sequence some samples and loops at first. Get samples free, with just Google searches. Get used to working with Audio and MIDI tracks. You don't need fancy expensive software like Ableton right away. Reaper is inexpensive, and Ableton has a lite version that is free to try.

Being a professional producer of over 17 years, and making electronic dance music prior to that since I was 8... I can unequivocally tell you that there is only one route; Practice practice practice, listen listen listen. Use your ears, spend a lot of hours, see what works at clubs. "Practice makes perfect""Passion makes persistence"

Youtube will be your best teacher. I started writing electronic music in high school and I had absolutely no music theory knowledge at the time. I torrented Logic Pro 7, then later Ableton (torrenting is fine imo as long you eventually buy the product) and started watching youtube tutorials and making shitty songs. As long as you keep producing and practicing you will see the improvement with every song you make.

I have been learning FL Studio for a few months now.. I play around with it once a week for half an hour or so, and I've found that learning how to make "a song" is VERY EASY. But making a song that sounds good is INCREDIBLY COMPLICATED! The reason it's complicated is that when you have a sound in your head that you want to create, you've got a specific sound... so you have to search through about 1000 different sounds on FL Studio to find it, but you'll find one that's ALMOST RIGHT and you'll have to use special effects to make it exactly how you want it. To memorize what all these sounds sound like and how to find them, you need to spend HOURSSSS listening to each sound.

Learn all the basic tricks like using sidechaining, using reverb, compression, eq etc. Your music needs to be on the same level of production quality as the professional producers but must also stand out somehow. This can be done musically with say an incredible melody or really catchy riff or bassline or it can be done sonically by processing a synth sound or a sample in a unique and fresh way. Often it will take both of these to make a hit record. Your track s will need something that is musically memorable and will need to sound fresh with regards to sound design.

For me, the thing that really taught me a lot was making mash ups so mix an acapella over a dub or instrumental version of a track. This got me used to the software and inevitably led me into producing remixes which is kind of where I still am today. I have produced a handful of original tracks but tend to remix generally. I’m not afraid to say I still use Acid Pro for the ease of beatmapping acapellas to knock together a quick mashup of the latest tracks for an upcoming set.

To create electronic music, there are a few things you need: 1. A good DAW (Digital Audio Workstation). I think Image Line FL Studio is the ideal one.2. A few drum and vocal sample packs.3. A selection of VST (Virtual Studio Technology) or RTAS (Real Time Audio Suite) synths. FL Studio comes with certain ones, but a couple other good ones are Native Instruments Kontakt, Native Instruments Massive, Lennar Digital Sylenth1, ReFX Nexus, and ReFX Nexus2.4. Knowledge of how to use the DAW and Synths you have.5. Creativity For more detail, here is an article that explains it in depth: How To Make EDM - The Beginners Guide | ESA Records | EDM Even though the article doesn't recommend Image Line FL Studio as a DAW, I still think it's the best one.

If you affect even 1 person through your music, thats success. -deadmau5. And about how to do it? Simple. Make not just good but exceptional music and that comes from Innovation, experimentation, experience, learning and practicing. Its a tough road, If by success you mean money and fame then it's easier, just make good generic tracks and get signed to a small label then aim for a medium one then make contacts with other producers and then when you are sure that you are ready for a big shot, spend all time promoting your work and sending out demos to the big guns.

Honestly, the best way to start can be as simple as buying a DAW and just messing around. See what you can come up with with basic production knowledge before you begin to focus too much on what genre and how loud your track is. This is by far the best way to create something unique in the music scene.

learning the fundamentals of music would be a big start. make sure you learn about and understand the elements of any musical piece (form, melody, harmony, timbre, and rhythm) while you are learning how to make your own.  if you are very motivated private instruction might be more useful and efficient than traditional schooling.

well,  you have a computer so I suppose you could just start if your passion lies in creating the music you should be all set but perhaps there's another question you should be asking (how do I find artists to collaborate with? how do I make money doing it?) either way, the best way to get started on anything is to do so

I'd recommend you listen to many artists from different countries as much as you can. Some you will find yourself fond of and be influenced with their style and that will motivate you to compose your own. I suggest you to study Ableton Live, which is the easiest DAW around and let you work in the studio and perform live. Import the track of your favourite producers and study their structure, or how the different elements progress over time. And collaborate: there’s nothing better to work with other people and exchange techniques and ideas.

A computer, software (DAW), and headphones or speakers is all you need to make electronic music in 2018. With those three things, you can create basic musical ideas and transform them into finished songs that you can show your family, friends, and the world.

Look in to the different kinds of DAWs (digital audio workstation) online and see which one looks the most appealing to you. There are many different kinds of daws but the most popular are FL studio, Ableton, and Pro Tools. These are the most commonly used among the top house and techno djs. You’re already many steps ahead with your knowledge of music theory so go download a DAW and watch some tutorial videos and you should be set!

There is no set pattern for getting good at Music production, the only key is to understand Music theory and, creativity. Let your mind wonder, think creatively, and practice and practice. For music production there is no specific time duration for learning some people make good music within a year, some take 2 and some even take more than that. Its a long process but totally worth it. Key points: Learn music theory.Practice.(a lot of it)Patience is most important.Hope this helps.

I agree that the tools don't make the product, but I find that FLStudio is/can be a very deep program. Most electronic music is about movement, little nuances and flourishes. FL is more than capable of this, in fact, with parameter automation it beats almost any DAW on the market. The peak controller and formula controller are almost unique, the only comparison would be synthesis programs like Reaktor, Max, or Supercollider.  That being said, FL has flaws but is great for EDM.
